crab: Exoskeleton texture: Crabs typically have a rougher, more textured exoskeleton compared to the smoother exoskeleton of many beetles.
Number of legs: Crabs have ten legs (including claws), while beetles typically have six legs.
Claws: Crabs have prominent claws (chelae) on their front pair of legs, which beetles usually lack.
Body shape: Crabs have a broader, flatter body shape, whereas beetles tend to have more elongated and rounded bodies.
Antennae: Beetles have clearly visible antennae, which crabs either lack or have much shorter antennae that are not as prominent.
Eyes: Crabs usually have stalked eyes that are set further apart, while beetles have compound eyes that are typically closer together.
Habitat: Crabs are generally associated with aquatic or near-water environments, while beetles are often found on land in various habitats.

Curved dorsal fin: Dolphin dorsal fins usually have a more hooked or curved shape compared to the straight or triangular fin of a shark.
Beak-like snout: Dolphins typically have a distinct, elongated snout, whereas sharks have a more rounded or conical snout.
Smooth skin: Dolphins have smooth, rubbery skin, while sharks have rougher skin made up of tiny scales called dermal denticles.
Horizontal tail fluke: Dolphins have a horizontal tail fluke that moves up and down, whereas sharks have a vertical tail fin that moves side to side.
Playful behavior: Dolphins are often seen leaping out of the water and engaging in playful activities, while sharks tend to move more steadily and with purpose.
Blowhole: Dolphins have a single blowhole on top of their heads for breathing, whereas sharks do not have blowholes.
Smaller pectoral fins: Dolphins typically have smaller, more streamlined pectoral fins compared to the larger ones found on sharks.
Social behavior: Dolphins are often seen in pods or groups, whereas many species of sharks are more solitary.

Blades: Lawn mowers have rotating blades underneath or at the front, whereas tanks do not.
Operator seating: Lawn mowers typically have a single seat or a standing platform for an operator, often with handlebars. Tanks have enclosed cabins and space for multiple crew members.

Engine placement: Lawn mower engines are usually visible either at the front or rear, while tank engines are enclosed within the armored structure.

Body shape: Seals have a more streamlined, elongated body shape, while turtles have a hard, rounded shell.
Skin texture: Seals typically have a sleek, smooth skin covered in short hair, while turtles have a hard, textured shell.

Nostrils: Seals have visible nostrils on their snouts, while turtles have nostrils close to the front of their faces, often less noticeable.
Habitat: Seals are often found on rocky shores or ice, whereas turtles are more likely to be seen on sandy beaches or in the water.

dorsal fin shape: Sharks typically have a triangular dorsal fin, while dolphins have a more curved or hooked dorsal fin.
body shape: Sharks generally have a more streamlined, torpedo-like body shape, whereas dolphins have a more elongated and slender body.
tail fin: A shark's tail fin (caudal fin) is generally vertical, while a dolphin's tail fin is horizontal.
skin texture: Sharks have rough, sandpaper-like skin, while dolphins have smooth, rubbery skin.
gill slits: Sharks have visible gill slits on the sides of their heads, while dolphins do not have gill slits and instead have a blowhole on top of their heads.
pectoral fins: Shark pectoral fins are typically more angled and rigid, while dolphin pectoral fins are more rounded and flexible.
teeth: Sharks have multiple rows of sharp, triangular teeth, while dolphins have more uniform, cone-shaped teeth.
coloration: Sharks often have more muted, darker colors to blend in with the ocean floor, whereas dolphins tend to have lighter, greyish to blueish tones.
Body Shape: Sharks generally have a more streamlined, torpedo-shaped body, whereas whales have a bulkier body.
Tail Fin: Sharks have a vertical tail fin (caudal fin) that moves side to side, while whales have a horizontal tail fin that moves up and down.
Skin Texture: Sharks usually have rough, sandpaper-like skin due to tiny scales called dermal denticles, whereas whales have smoother skin.
Gill Slits: Sharks have multiple visible gill slits on the sides of their heads, typically five to seven, whereas whales have a single blowhole or pair of blowholes on top of their heads.
Dorsal Fin Shape: Shark dorsal fins are generally more pointed and erect compared to the more rounded or falcate (sickle-shaped) dorsal fins of many whales.
Teeth: Sharks have numerous sharp, triangular teeth that are continuously replaced, while whales may have baleen plates for filtering food or more uniform, peg-like teeth.
Mouth Position: A shark's mouth is typically located on the underside of its head, while a whale's mouth is located on the front of the head.
Movement: Sharks often exhibit side-to-side swimming motion due to their vertical tail, while whales have an up-and-down undulating swimming motion.
Size and Scale: While some sharks can be large, whales are generally much larger overall, with some species like the blue whale being the largest animals on Earth.

Shell shape: Snails typically have a spiral-shaped shell, while crabs have a more flattened, broad shell.
Body structure: Snails have a long, soft body with a distinct head and foot, whereas crabs have a segmented body with a hard exoskeleton.
Legs: Snails lack visible limbs, while crabs have multiple legs, usually ten.
Antennae: Snails have two pairs of tentacles on their heads, while crabs generally have large pincers (claws) and small antennae.
Movement: Snails usually move slowly by gliding on their muscular foot, while crabs scuttle sideways or walk on their legs.
Habitat: Snails are often found on land, in freshwater, or in marine environments, whereas crabs are usually found near the sea, either on the shore or underwater.

Rails/tracks: Trains run on tracks, whereas tanks do not.
Long, connected carriages: Trains have multiple connected cars, while tanks are single vehicles.
Engine car: Trains often have a distinct engine or locomotive car at the front.
Absence of turret: Trains do not have turrets, which are common on tanks.
Passenger windows: Trains often have rows of windows for passengers, unlike tanks.
Large, smooth wheels: Trains have large, smooth wheels compared to the caterpillar tracks on tanks.
Overhead electrical lines: Some trains use overhead lines for power, while tanks do not.
Railroad signals and crossings: Indications of railway infrastructure would be present around a train.
Rails or tracks: Trains run on tracks, while buses run on roads.
Locomotive: Trains often have a separate locomotive unit either at the front or throughout, whereas buses do not.
Length: Trains are typically much longer with multiple carriages compared to the single-unit structure of buses.
Overhead lines or pantographs: Trains might have overhead electrical wires or pantographs, buses do not.
Platforms: Trains are often seen next to raised platforms in stations, while buses have curb-height stops.
Train station architecture: Train stations often feature specific structures like long platforms, tracks, and train-specific signage.
Couplers: The connecting mechanism between train cars, known as couplers, are visible linking the carriages.
Train signal lights: Specific signaling systems along the tracks indicating train presence and movement.
Multiple doors: Trains have multiple doors along the sides for passenger entry, compared to usually fewer on a bus.

Size: Wolves are significantly larger than rabbits.
Fur color: Wolves typically have gray, white, black, or tan fur, while rabbits have a wider variety including browns, grays, and whites.
Ears: Wolves have short, rounded ears; rabbits have long, upright ears.
Tail: Wolves have long, bushy tails; rabbits have short, fluffy tails.
Snout: Wolves have long, pronounced snouts; rabbits have short, flat faces.
Eyes: Wolves have forward-facing eyes with a more intense gaze; rabbits have large, more side-placed eyes.
Paws/Feet: Wolves have large paws with claws; rabbits have smaller, padded feet adapted for hopping.
Body structure: Wolves have a more elongated and muscular body; rabbits have a more rounded and compact body.
Teeth: Wolves have sharp, carnivorous teeth; rabbits have large, prominent incisors designed for gnawing on vegetation.
General habitat setting: Wolves are often depicted in forest or wilderness settings; rabbits are more likely shown in grassy or burrowed environments.

**Small Size**: Worms are generally much smaller in length and diameter compared to snakes.
**Absence of Scales**: Worms have smooth, moist skin, whereas snakes have dry, scaly skin.
**Segmented Body**: Worms have a visibly segmented body, while snakes do not.
**Lack of Eyes and Eyelids**: Worms usually lack prominent eyes; if they have eyes, they are very rudimentary.
**Lack of Limbs**: Worms have no limbs at all, whereas some snakes may have vestigial limbs or markings where limbs would be.
**Simple Head Structure**: Worms lack the distinct head shape found in snakes; they don't have a defined neck or facial features.
**Movement Pattern**: Worms move by contracting their body segments in a wave-like motion, whereas snakes slither in a more fluid, lateral or S-shaped motion.
**Moist Environment**: Worms are often found in moist, soil-rich environments, which might be an indicative feature in a photo's background.
